captions.text:
Hi I'm Ty Brown with dogbehavioronline.com.
I'm here in Riverton, Utah today teaching

you how to train a dog. The purpose of today's
training is teaching you how to potty train

a dog. Now potty training a dog is step number
one for any dog when it comes into the home.

Nobody likes to clean up accidents and so
it is very important from a young age to teach

your dog where it is appropriate to go to
the bathroom and where it's not. There is

four major steps that you need to keep in
mind when you are potty training a dog. The

first one is prevention. Prevention is a huge
part of potty training a dog. By prevention

I mean never allowing it to happen in the
first place. The way to accomplish that is

through proper supervision and that takes
two different ways. Number one when you're

home you should keep the dog with you. Often
times with a young puppy or a dog that is

not house trained or potty trained yet I'll
even keep the dog on a leash in the house

with me so that he can't get away and sneak
behind the couch and go to the bathroom. When

I'm gone then I'll use something like a crate
so that the dog is in a place where he is

not going to go to the bathroom and in doing
that by keeping the dog with me and keeping

the dog in the crate I can prevent the dog
from going to the bathroom in the first place.

The second step to potty training a dog is
encouraging the proper behavior. Now this

is pretty easy. You take your dog outside
to go to the bathroom and when he does go

to the bathroom you make it a wonderful occasion
for him. You praise him, you pet him. If you

have a treat you give him a treat. What you
want to do is over and over and over associate

a word such as go to the bathroom. He goes
to the bathroom, you give him a treat and

soon he starts to realize boy this sure is
fun to go to the bathroom outside. The third

step to potty training a dog is correcting
the bad behavior when it does happen. Even

though you are supervising the dog by the
use of the crate and by keeping him on a leash,

and even though you are encouraging him to
go to the bathroom outside he is still going

to have some accidents and so when he does
you quickly want to tell him no firmly as

you rush him outside using the leash and get
him outside to go to the bathroom there. The

last thing you want to do in potty training
a dog is to get your dog on a schedule and

that's a food schedule and a bathroom schedule.
Take your dog out to the bathroom first thing

in the morning and last thing at night, directly
after eating, one hour after eating, any time

you take your dog out of the crate and any
other time you feel like your dog needs to

go to the bathroom. Also get your dog on a
food schedule. For dogs six months and younger

they should be eating three times a day. Dogs
from six months to a year should be eating

two times a day and so what you want to do
is get a dog on a schedule of eating and that

way you know when he needs to go to the bathroom.
By following these four steps you'll successfully
potty train your dog.

title: Dog Training Tips : How to Potty-Train Your Dog

comments.text:
I have an 11 month old German Shepherd that is becoming problematic. I 
predict his behavior is only going to worsen. He doesnt come when called, 
he doesnt sit (after I spent months training him to come and to sit). His 
hearing is selective. Hes becoming aggressive. He is constantly play 
biting. He still will not potty train, which is my biggest issue with him. 
He just had diarrhea all over my Karastan rug in the dining room. I know 
youre not supposed to do it because its going to make them "fear" you and 
all that, but I went ahead and rubbed his nose in it. It was just a minute 
after he had eliminated in the dining room. I have crate trained him from 
day 1. That doesnt work. He pisses and shits in his crate. He cant hold 
himself. He is irregular with when he goes. It has nothing to do with when 
he eats or drinks. He eats and drinks on a consistent basis. First thing in 
the morning, and no later than 4pm. He just goes to the bathroom at 
irregular times, and he WILL piss and shit where he sleeps. He just does it 
then barks for me to come and clean it up. Im thinking of sending him to 
the pound because im really disappointing with him and dont know what to do 
anymore.﻿
comments.author: GODISNOTGREAT

comments.text:
+GODISNOTGREAT 
Good grief! Lots of problems with this GS.
I have had the breed for years you must take them out right after they eat 
and stay out until they eliminate.
I train behavior problems with a shock collar, not tricks or cute 
activities, and never for house breaking use.
If the odor from his previous bathroom relief in the house is not 
completely eliminated the smell will trigger a repeat event and rubbing 
their nose in it never works.
You must gain respect, GS's have a strong hierarchical instinct so you must 
be the leader (Alpha) or expect to be repeatedly challenged.
comments.author: Bass Player

I think I have a very complicated situation and I don't know where to start 
explaining. I am based in Saudi Arabia and dogs here aren't really pets or 
even animals for most people (No offense to Arabs).

I found my dog, a German Shepherd, walking aimlessly in the highway. I took 
him in before something bad happens. He's been with me for over two months 
now and my only problem with him is that he almost always steps on his poop.

Now, I can't take him for a walk outside because I'm afraid people might do 
something to him. I've never heard of friends of mine who have dogs or have 
seen people walking their dogs so basically my dog stays in my room and I 
have built for him an enclosed space near the bathroom. I made it because 
he bites things even if I had already bought him stuff for his teeth. Also, 
I work from 2-10 PM. When I get home  his space is just a mess with his 
poop all over and on his paws so most days he gets a shower. Though, I've 
made a routine with him that I feed him on a particular time and I pick up 
his poop which I kinda figured out when he does it but its just the time 
when I'm sleeping or when I'm away that he steps on his poop.

Please help.﻿

comments.text:
+Cyril George We had a dog that did that--I swear she held it for over a 
day when we took 8 hour trips to visit my in-laws. I didn't do this, but 
here's my suggestion. It may be disgusting sounding, but try taking some of 
the dog's poop in a plastic container to put at an appropriate spot in a 
new place. When he smells himself it might encourage him to do his business 
because that's how dogs think. That first dog we had was such a head case 
when it came to going potty. I had to use what I learned in my college 
Psych 101 course to figure her out.
comments.author: THERESA MUNROE

comments.text:
This is a very common thing....often dogs will look to eat grass if they 
have digestion issues, or if their stomach is upset. Not the ONLY reason, 
but that's very often the case. So when you see him going after grass like 
it's the yummiest thing in the world, maybe you can correlate that with a 
change in food, or feeding amounts or times, or too many snacks, etc.... 
Hope this helps!
comments.author: DawgieStyleTraining

force fed it to her, like you would a pill. You know tilt the head back,

house!!!!

2 weeks off of work to be with your new dog. This is a lot of work but it 
did work with me amazingly well but, I just took my dog outside every half 
an hour, and did the praising when she did go potty outside. if she had an 
accident inside I would make her sit beside her accident and give her a 
stern lecture on using he house as a toilet shaking my finger at her , and 
using a stern voice. Had her 80% trained in a week.
